label: Letter from Samuel H. Parsons to Nathanael Greene
description: Letter from Samuel H. Parsons to Nathanael Greene regarding the general state of political affairs as the war draws to a close. General Parsons voices his concerns on the activities of Congress and his doubt that military officers will have a voice in political affairs post-war.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Samuel H. Parsons to Nathanael Greene regarding the general state of political affairs as the war draws to a close. General Parsons voices his concerns on the activities of Congress and his doubt that military officers will have a voice in political affairs post-war.

metadata.label: Access Note

metadata.label: Digitization Specifications

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
[Samuel H. Parsons to Nathanael Greene
July 22, 1780
[RvW Box 1 Folder 15; MSS. – A.L.S.]]

Danbury 22nd July 1780
Dear Sir
I am honor'd with your's of the 20th
and thank you for the Information contain'd
in it. I am fully of Opinion with you
that the object of the Operations this Season
is great [and] very important, and the Spirit of
the Country is so much elated with the pleasing
Prospect that no man, especially an Officer, 
is at Liberty to communicate Doubts respect-
-ing our Success without risqing [sic] the total Loss
of Reputation; this advantage at least is
to be derivd from their Expectations, that
in proportion as they wish our Success, they
must exert themselves to comply with 
every Demand, indeed I don't hesitate
to assure them, that the General will
not undertake the Reduction of N York,
unless every Requisition is fully complied 
with; that any, the least, Departure from
the Letter of the Requisitions endangers
the total blasting their Hopes [and] Wishes -
- for my own part, I consider this the
most important attempt we can make
,Success in this finally ends the War
;tis an arduous Business embaras'd with
[End Page 1]
great [and] almost unsurmountable [sic] Difficulties
[ink blot] to succeed forever establishes our Charac-
-ter as a People, to fail will be Distress
and heightned [sic] Misery to our Country if
not infalible ruine [sic]; to attempt
nothing is nearly as fatal, and where
the Object can be found which promises
certain Success [and] which saves us from 
the Consequences of attempting nothing 
or failing in our attempts, I am at Loss
- if Naval Force is necessary, shall
we have one adequate to our Wants?
- I know great Exertions will be necessary
[and] very many Instances of extending
military Force, where legal Provisions
are inadequate to the purposes, must be
found this Campaign, if the attempt
is made nothing which Power can
effect against our Friends or Enemies
must be left untried –
I wish my Name to be annex'd to 
any Representation made  by the General 
Officers on the Subject Matter of
[End Page 2]
their former Application to Congress
- for my part I think we have been trifled
with too long [and] that any measures, even
at this important Crises, are warrantable
I don't see that those who refuse us Justice
despise our Sacrifices [and] degrade our Characters
below the Level, even of a private Soldier
are intitled [sic] to our Services, I do not believe
in their Honor or Honesty and am certain 
when we are no more wanted, we can form 
no Expectations from them. I am willing
to serve my Country, but don't choose to be-
-come the Dupe of any Man or Bodies of
Men. The General's Fortunes I will
follow through every Stage of this Contest
;but from this Determination I do not
ingage [sic] to follow Congress or pursue their
Measures -
The Enemy are proceeding to
Suffolk County to complete the Theft
fo the Inhabitants Cattle
I am Dr Sr. [Dear Sir] with Esteem [and] Respect
yr obedt Servt [your obedient Servant]
Sam H. Parsons
General Green [sic]
[End Page 3]
[Endorsed: written sideways]
From Genl. [General] Parsons
July 22d. 1780.
57
[End Page 4]
